DOC.HEAD: Andean Presidents Agree to Promote Economic Integration
DOC.TEXT: The five presidents of the Andean Pact, meeting on the remote Galapagos Islands, agreed Monday to help promote the integration of their countries' economies and eventually use a common currency. The presidents of Ecuador, Colombia, Venezuela, Peru and Bolivia signed the ``Declaration of the Galapagos'' in a ceremony in Puerto Ayora on the island of Santa Cruz. Presidents Rodrigo Borja of Ecuador, Virgilio Barco of Colombia, Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, Alan Garcia of Peru and Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia were to return to the Ecuadoran mainland, 600 miles away, before nightfall. But first the leaders planned to visit several of the archipelago's islands to see the unique plant and animal life, including giant tortoises, land and marine iguanas, seals and species of birds found nowhere else on Earth. Upon their return to the mainland city of Guayaquil late Monday, the four visiting presidents were scheduled to immediately fly home. The five presidents arrived Sunday in the Galapagos and met in seclusion aboard a navy ship. The document signed Monday was prepared last week by the foreign ministers of the five nations meeting in Guayaquil, Ecuador's most populous city and its primary port. In the document the five presidents also agreed to forsake ``the use of force'' to resolve disputes among member nations of the Andean Pact and to ``abstain from actions against the territorial integrity'' of members. In 1981 Ecuador and Peru fought a four-day border war. It was sparked by Ecuador's long-standing claim of sovereignty over a large tract of Amazon jungle in northeastern Peru. The five presidents also signed a separate document in which they set goals they hoped to achieve in integrating their countries' economies, including a common currency. No date for the common currency was divulged. ``The creation of the European Common Market has indicated to us the direction in which the world is advancing,'' Perez said in a press conference in Puerto Ayora's municipal headquarters, where the signing ceremony took place. Garcia called the Galapagos' summit ``the most important meeting the Andean Pact has had'' in its 20 years of existence. In a press conference in Guayaquil Sunday before the presidents flew to the Galapagos Islands, Paz Zamora said, ``If we don't make a great effort, the Andean Pact is going to die on us.'' In an attempt to rejuvenate the Andean Pact, the five presidents agreed this year to meet every six months. The last meeting was in May in Cartagena, Colombia, where President Bush is scheduled to meet in February for a drug summit with Barco and other Latin leaders. It is one of the oldest of a half dozen regional organizations that have tried unsuccessfully to achieve economic integration. In recent years trade among the five Andean nations has declined due to high tariffs.
